oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Unequal contribution of native South African phylogeographic lineages to the invasion of the African clawed frog, Xenopus laevis, in Europe
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: De Busschere, Charlotte
Courant, Julien
Herrel, Anthony
Rebelo, Rui
RÃ¶dder, Dennis

oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: theme:invasion pathway
African clawed frog
South Africa
phylogeography
invasive species
invasion pathway
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>Due to both deliberate and accidental introductions, invasive African Clawed Frog (<jats:italic>Xenopus laevis</jats:italic>) populations have become established worldwide. In this study, we investigate the geographic origins of invasive<jats:italic>X. laevis</jats:italic>populations in France and Portugal using the phylogeographic structure of<jats:italic>X. laevis</jats:italic>in its native South African range. In total, 80 individuals from the whole area known to be invaded in France and Portugal were analysed for two mitochondrial and three nuclear genes, allowing a comparison with 185 specimens from the native range. Our results show that native phylogeographic lineages have contributed differently to invasive European<jats:italic>X. laevis</jats:italic>populations. In Portugal, genetic and historical data suggest a single colonization event involving a small number of individuals from the south-western Cape region in South Africa. In contrast, French invasive<jats:italic>X. laevis</jats:italic>encompass two distinct native phylogeographic lineages, i.e., one from the south-western Cape region and one from the northern regions of South Africa. The French<jats:italic>X. laevis</jats:italic>population is the first example of a<jats:italic>X. laevis</jats:italic>invasion involving multiple lineages. Moreover, the lack of population structure based on nuclear DNA suggests a potential role for admixture within the invasive French population.</jats:p>
